data.text: Frame Wobble when Cycle Touring Fully Loaded

Frame wobble. NOT from speed. What am I doing wrong? I relocated the weight from the front panniers to the rear and found that if I pushed my weight rear-ward on the saddle it also helped, but, time for a new bike? Existing is a 1986 Specialized Expedition, rebuilt from the ground, up. 95% going to purchase a KONA Sutra and hope not to have it inherit the issues, but ...
I've had wobbling from low tire pressure...
data.author: Charles V. Lemieux

data.text: All that weight causes its own gravitational pull.
data.author: Roger Komula

data.text: everytime he starts pedaling I see ripples in my coffee.
data.author: Tom Skinner

data.text: that's not a wobble, downhill makes you shift in and out dimensionally.
data.author: Roger Komula

data.text: Sounds like the wheels...check everything, spoke tension, hubs, pressure and check if it's true.
data.author: Jesse Alèjandro

data.text: Do you feel it mostly in the handlebars?
data.author: Jordan Roberto

data.text: Road bike frame woble will continue on the sutra get a proper touring frame and tyres
data.author: Menno Pieters

data.text: a Kona sutra is a proper all steel touring bike
data.author: Mary Cosentino-Cathey

data.text: The Specialized Expedition is widely held to be one of the best touring bikes ever built, my friend. Thanks, though.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: when does it wobble? on descents? rough pavement? when fully unloaded, does it still wobble under given circumstances?
data.author: Ed Kriege

data.text: Try removing/reducing 1 or 2 bags at a time to diagnose the issue. I would start with the large handlebar bag.
data.author: Whan-Soo James Kang

data.text: large handlebar bag seems to be everyone's target but it only had my tablet, my powerbank, my wallet, a small pair of binoculars, my maps and my USB cables and chargers. Additionally, whether or not there was water in my HVB bottle did not seem to affect things. Not the HB bag. Thanks, though.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Too much weight up front. You could try repacking with the heavier stuff at the bottom of the bags. I recently carried 18kg but only had 4kg on the front which, balanced perfectly.
data.author: Michael Richards

data.text: I did move the contents from front to rear and that seemed to help.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Is your headset okay?
data.author: Charlotte Kramer

data.text: How much does all your luggage weigh? Isn't it too much?
data.author: Олег Тройно

data.text: This happens to me a lot, This problem is caused by excess weight in the front, especially in the handlebar bag.
data.author: غويلب محمد رضا

data.text: Rear panniers set too far back, move them further forward on the rear pannier rack.
data.author: Lucy Wells

data.text: Excellent advice. Thanks!
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: You're feeling the steel flexing Lower your weight closer to the axle
data.author: Jack Carlson

data.text: Remove handlebar bag, if wobble continues remove front paniers as a test. How much do those front bags weigh?
data.author: Bob Sinko

data.text: You are the FIRST one to even ask! Too much, it seemsI had my food in there - mostly nuts, trail mix and gorp, some Knoor Noodles and some Carnation Instant Breakfast. Fronts bags sit lower than the axle and all the other advice I hade ever read said "put weight forward". When I put the food in the rear and the clothes in the front it was much, much better. Others have advised moving the bags to get more weight "between" the axles. This makes sense, too. Not the HB bag, though. It's half empty.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: I'm no expert (but this is fb so what the hell) but I'm going to suggest that the issue is that it's a steel frame and steel flexes and does so more with every additional bit of weight - and by the looks of it you are carrying a LOT of weight. I recently rode a Jamis Aurora Elite - a touring road bike that comes with a rack as standard - around the UK for two weeks, with probably half the weight you're carrying, and the frame/fork flexed/'wobbled' noticeably if I wiggled the bars - I have a feeling most of the flex was in the fork but hard to tell. If you want a 'rigid' feel you'll probably have to go aluminium or perhaps a carbon-forked bike - I felt no issues on my similarly-loaded Fargo in Baja last winter but then that was largely off-road and on 3" tubeless low-pressure tires..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: Adam frame flex is at a lower frequency than wobbling can occur .. basic physics .. the frame is essentially inert while only subject to torsion and vertical force .. it can only be the front wheel or something directly connected to the wheel (fork)
data.author: Lnx Hcrib

data.text: That makes sense - it all depends on what he actually meant by ‘wobble’..
data.author: Adam Macer

data.text: 700c wheels are just not conducive to heavy loads, I’d go for an expedition bike with 26in wheels like the Rohloff nomad by Thorn cycles.
data.author: Joe Francis

data.text: you saved me writing thanks
data.author: Andrew Winfield

data.text: , I still have a 700c traditional English touring bike but only use it for very lite load touring, about 20 years ago I bought a thorn nomad mk1 and about 5 years ago I bought a nomad mk2 with rohloff, they are stable as hell, in fact they are more stable heavily loaded.
data.author: Joe Francis

data.text: pick mine up end of the month
data.author: Guy Willing

data.text: I 100% agree. I had a Surly LHT and used to get frame wobble a lot when fully loaded. That coupled with not being able to stop the bike on steep long descents, I had a custom Co-Motion Pangea with 26" wheels, Rohloff with Gates belt drive built for me in 2016. Frame wobble gone.
data.author: Len DeMoss

data.text: too small wheels? Sorry I don't know that metrics:/
data.author: Eo Eo

data.text: agree <700cc wheels are better for road touring…I use 27.5 tubeless carbon wheels for road
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: right 26 inch double rim wheels and 36 Stainlesssteel spokes with 1,5 Schwalbe Marathon Plus. tires. The best you can imagine. I have done it with a total weight including myself (110 kgs) of 140 kgs from Rotterdam to Turkey. Not any problem. It was a secondhand bicycle which I assembled myself. No need to buy an expensive bike. I bought a simple Giant ATB with V Brakes for 150 Euro. Additional expenses were abt 350 euro.
data.author: René Visser

data.text: had a Thorn Sherpa and a Thorn nomad and they were both great bikes but much prefer 700c/29er if only for rolling over things better. A 26" Ryde Grizzly with Rohloff will get you to heck and back but a solid 700c/29er wheel will be just fine.
data.author: Paul Schmidt

data.text: , it old mountain bike size wheels, 26ins as opposed to 700c that are much bigger
data.author: Joe Francis

data.text: Thanks!
data.author: Eo Eo

data.text: , it depends on the speed you ride and age fitness, I ride 700c most days, but for heavy duty touring I use 26in 36 spoke rims and 1.5 marathon plus tyres, you just can’t get tyres like that on a 700c bike. I also lost loads of rear drive side spokes on 700c dished wheels, just couldn’t handle any mild of road cycling. 26in Rohloff rear with no dish 36 spoke wheel is heavy duty and never let me down yet. But I accept most bikes and frames are a subjective choice and we all have our preferences. I still love my 700c British tourer and have Sputnik rims on deor Deore xt hubs 36 DT Swiss spokes. Great wheels but maximum tyre is 32mm. Great for fast light short tours but I’d never take it out of Europe. Horses for courses I suppose.
data.author: Joe Francis

data.text: in my experience most of the wobble is coming from "loose" front pannier bags. you get used to it after some time. Maybe better fixation of front panniers helps, but i didn't try that...
data.author: Robert Fröming

data.text: Your bike and wheels will probably have a weight limit. Check what it is then weigh yourself, your bike and the luggage add it all up and see if it exceeds your bikes weight limit.
data.author: Shaun Marshall

data.text: headset and tire pressure come to find .. otherwise wheel alignment and true it's only happened to me with a headset that was failing and low tire pressure I pack about 8-10kg on the front. 15-18kg rear, for reference, and ride an eighties steel frame. Other than that it's wheel overloading. Are you using high-load wheels?
data.author: Lnx Hcrib

data.text: To much luggage. As simple as that. 😁
data.author: Trygve Rolfsnes

data.text: My trek 520 does this in high speeds (35km) if I'm not careful with the weight distribution up front. This is even though I"m using hand-built, extra strong DT Swiss rims and 42mm Schwalbe Marathons.
data.author: Þórður Ólafur Þórðarson

data.text: If its on descent? Check your bake pads are aligned equally, if one pad hits the rim before the other it can create a wobble that reverberates into the frame.
data.author: Paul Hickson

data.text: No, it was a weight distribution issue. It showed up at the end of the driveway when I hit the first bump. I thought I just needed to learn how to handle the bike. Nope. Weight in the wrong spots. Some people here have confirmed my suspicions. Others assume I am overloaded but have not asked what I am carrying. 🙁
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Heavier duty wheels for heavier loads would reduce the wobble factor
data.author: David Hugh Mashburn

data.text: This was my Iron Horse mtn bike loaded for a test ride. I decided I dint like the panniers on the front Forks and removed them before I started touring.
data.author: Gary Palmer

data.text: I would suggest much more stuff than you need. Cut the entire load to a third of what you are carrying now. And redistribute. Ditch the front panniers for smaller stuff sacks.

data.text: I had same idea
data.author: Thorsten Schneemann

data.text: Try to move the font paniers forward and backward if you can. The wobble may come from the weight that is not aligned vertically with the wheel axis.
data.author: Mathieu Goulet

data.text: Too much weight in that huge handle bar bag? Remove bar bag and see if wobble gone. I have 2006 version of this Arkel pannier set and they are great. However only a small bar bag. Also I mounted front panniers high on a Old Man Mountain Sherpa rack. Never any wobble.
data.author: Joe Trudo

data.text: Put all the heavy stuff in the bottom of the panniers. Get the center of gravity as LOW as possible. You've got your front load too high.
data.author: Dave Gilbert

data.text: Food was in the front, lower than the back. I moved it to the back and it was better. (Clothes in the front.)
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: You’ll love that Kona. But I have toured for months at a time, and it looks like you need to cut back on gear. Way to go though! 🚲🚲🚲🚲

data.text: I looked at the photo and thought there were two bikes there, I would wobble too if I had that much weight hung on me.
data.author: Patrick Francis

data.text: There is a ton of stuff packed on the front of that bike. I'd definitely lighten the front dramatically.
data.author: Scott Fetcko

data.text: Um, do you know how full those panniers are? Do you know what is in them?
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Well lets say for the sake of argument there isn't much at all in them and there is very little weight. Then maybe you don't need them and you did ask..... Have a good trip

data.text: I have a Kona sutra that does the trick but also don’t rock front panniers
data.author: Alex Swigert

data.text: My guess is that your bike is grossly overloaded. Golden rule for me is: any gear that won’t fit in a couple of rear Ortliebs, with topbag, stays at home. I have absolutely nothing on the front wheel or handlebars. With a bit of ingenuity, it’s amazing what you can do to shrink your touring kit.
data.author: Mike Fifield

data.text: I think it's partly the bike. I have 3 bikes newer than my Expedition and never had a wobble on them.

data.text: I have to agree .I went round the world on 2 rear panniers , tiny tent and a small pouch for sweets !

data.text: I have definitely travelled like that and cold, but redistributing weight - given that there are mounts on the forks - seemed like a good idea and that the rear was REALLY heavy.

data.text: You need 1/4 of what you're carrying in that picture.
data.author: Henri Hay

data.text: After much experimentation (4 years on the road with heavy loads) I've concluded 60% rear/ 40% front is best weight distribution.... but still nothing is perfect. A frame with stouter tubing will help. Knee pressing on the top tube will dampen shimmy to some degree.

data.text: …don’t like having any extra-weight at the front- it just works against my innate feeling to pull up on the handlebars to avoid a bump or a hole…

data.author: Damian Thomas

data.text: If wobbles without the bags, it can be a wheel that is not trued. A tire bead not seated properly on the rim. An air chamber that is not the correct diameter. A crack in the frame. Wheel axle not seated properly in the dropout. If wobbles only with the bags on, then too much weight on the front.
data.author: Nvlk Hn

data.text: Thanks. Only wobbles with the bags. I built and trued the wheels myself. They're good.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: What everybody else said there's a lot of weight upfront But also as much as I like those classic '80s touring bikes they were actually not that great because of being too flexy. If you really like carrying that much gear then you would be better served by something newer for sure and that Kona would be the ticket.
data.author: Paul Schmidt

data.text: I have an 1983 Specialized Expedition. Great bike, but it did tend to wobble a bit on the downhills.
data.author: Ken Francis

data.text: Cool!! I think from some of the non-assumptive feedback I need to make sure that the weight is behind the front axle and ahead of the rear. I definitely kept my weight low - I do understand the laws of physics! Love seeing another Expedition!

data.text: I retired mine at 62,000 miles. It's still sitting in my garage

data.text: Yeah wow, thats a lot of kit. Shed kit. And maybe a Koga World Traveller.

data.text: Roger Komula, damn, just seen this on your profile, those would be great for adding some more weight on the legs when touring lol https://www.facebook.com/100074445654408/posts/188831586941695/?app=fbl
data.author: Kevin Moore

data.text: My steel Surly Disk Trucker wobbles at first, but once I get rolling I can compensate and I get more confident so the wobble goes away. That said, that’s a LOT of gear for any bike. Lighten the front by half. You’d be amazed at how little you actually need. And remember, you’re not riding to Jupiter: if you really need something, you can buy it on the road. In my experience I leave more behind than I accumulate.
data.author: Loren Tripp

data.text: good point. Yes, starting off on a loaded touring bike results in bit ofwobble/twitchy activity. Hour or 2 usually disappears.
data.author: Joe Trudo

data.text: I found that, too. But.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: When i can cycled in Europe, Sweden and in Asia i only had 3 bags... Barely had 4-5 kg of package. If you pack suffient and only what your truly need you can get away with less. So your main problem is your carry weight.
data.author: Niklas Pedersen

data.text: are the speakers at the right voltage! if these have never been adjusted to the correct voltage in the many years you have been cycling with them, speedwoble can also occur. how is your tire tension? you said you ever rebuilt the bike completely, did the spokes come out? and have these been put back in the right way? (braided) Do you have the spokes at the right tension? if these have never been adjusted to the correct tension in the many years that you have already cycled with them, speed woble can also occur. how is your tire pressure? you mentioned you ever rebuilt the bike from scratch, have the spokes come out? and have they been put back in the correct way? (braided) you have a beautiful bike I wish you a lot of fun
data.author: Ben De Blok

data.text: Drinking too many 🍻🍺🍻🍺 🤔
data.author: Lee Carter

data.text: I had this problem and solved it by shifting the front panniers as far back as possible. In my case it was two clicks back on the Ortlieb adjustable rack. The problem went from being very shaky at 10mph to never happening.
data.author: Steve Rich

data.text: Thanks! I will try this. I did try to move the center of gravity to "between" the front and rear axles. i will work harder to do this on my next rip. Great advice! Thanks!
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: How long you travelling for seems excessive weight to me
data.author: Matty James Edge

data.text: Adjust your front pannier's hooks to locate them as far back on the rack as possible. The combined centre of gravity of your front load needs to be as close to the centre of steering as possible. Ideally slightly behind.
data.author: Mick Allan

data.text: Ii used to tour with a specialized pro flat bar...wobble wobble for sure. Switched to a Kona sutra about 3 years years ago. The 30 inch wheels and heavy frame keep me glued to the road with no wobble. Only thing I don't like is the toe camber and the bike's lack of agility/maneuverability. Overall, happy with my Kona for sure!
data.author: Cheryl Garrett

data.text: Physicist here: your front weight isn't your problem, it's your high-weight.
data.author: Phidias Chinaglia

data.text: Beautyful, but hevy. About water, yes, I also carried extra 3 liters this summer, when it was +30. Extra water is better than no water, been there, know it :) Good luck, Peter! :)
data.author: Albert Volkov

data.text: Carried 2 of 2L on the frame plus 650ml on the HB stem. Usually good for a day. Still ended up begging for water one day, but most days if I filled up once in the morning and once after supper I was good. (Thank you McDonald's! Free ice water!)
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Your post does not mention weight and weight is definitely a factor as well as where it is loaded. Just judging by the photo, you seem to be carrying quite a load on the front wheel which would definitely make the steering subject to many small overcorrections producing a wobble. My rule with bikepacking it to carry no more weight on my bike than I would carry on my back. For me that tops out at 50 pounds. I also try to keep the weight no more than 60% on the back and 40% on the front. I prefer 70/30 unless that extra weight is something I might consume along the day's ride such as water or food. You also need to balance between left and right. Overall, your bike looks suitable and I don't think a new bike would solve the issue. My advice would be to lighten the load and play with the distribution before buying another bike. (Of course, if you really want a new bike then any excuse is a good one!)
data.author: Bob Peltzer

data.text: Do you have any pics of the items you are carrying?
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: Maybe that 5 litre water bottle on the left hand side 🤔
data.author: Colin Brown

data.text: Have you tried pulling some weight from the front...?
data.author: Rodolfo Martinez

data.text: Old design not stiff enough. Discard half of your stuff and put the heaviest things to full frame bag.
data.author: Bartosz Sawicki

data.text: Frame is too weak.
data.author: Jörg Duurkoop

data.text: Way too much weight in handlebar area. I disagree with the comments that say “too much weight in front.” Front low-riding panniers are a good way to get weight distribution front to back, but the handlebar bag and water bottle and whatever you’ve got under the hb bag, that’s the first to get rid of. But less weight in general is certainly a good idea. Headset may need adjustment/replacement. I always replace caged bearings with loose bearings so there are more of them in there. My two cents worth.
data.author: Edwin Booth

data.text: concur
data.author: Tuan Truong

data.text: Also, and this is a really small thing, you could ditch the handlebar-mounted mirror and get the one I always recommend. The Take-a-Look glasses- or helmet-mounted mirror. I find it much better than the handlebar ones because 1) you just move you head a little bit to see everything behind (rather than look down and hope your handlebars are in the right position for the needed view); 2) they work so much better in the rain; 3)MUCH lighter; 4) live with helmet (or glasses) rather than on the bike, so you only need one of them for all your bikes; 5) discrete and elegant; 6) $15 to $18 on Amazon.
data.author: Edwin Booth

data.text: I agree. The weight up high (handlebar bag) is thr most likely destabiliser
data.author: James Ryan

data.text: not sure how much difference in weight by changing mirror....grams?. I think there would probably less important things to take out of those bags. Mirrors are great and they would not be the cause of his wobble.
data.author: Victoria Eckenroth

data.text: sounds like a fellow who has solved for one or more torsional oscillator equations in his life (as I have!)?
data.author: Phidias Chinaglia

data.text: he wouldn't risk inducing oscillation into his system if he removed the mirror from his bars - mirrors need to scanned to be effective.
data.author: Phidias Chinaglia

data.text: yes I know I use mine everyday
data.author: Victoria Eckenroth

data.text: Agree with you on the mirrors...personal preference is the only role different mirrors play aside the fact that I don't roll without one.
data.author: Richard Roussy

data.text: Handlebar bag had a tablet, small camera, wallet, maps, powerbank ... and the wobbles were not affected but whether or not there was water in the bottle. Handlebar bag was definitely NOT overweight.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: ditch the handlebar bag…top heavy wt will cause wobble
data.author: Dave Becker-Ellison

data.text: I'm a firm believer in front loading. I don't get wobble when my load is tight. Balance the heavy stuff close to axle and wedge it in with other gear so it can't move. Floppy loads=floppy rides. If you can't travel lighter, use a trailer to lighten the load on your bike frame.
data.author: Richard Roussy

data.text: Tried food in the front. Awful. Put it in the back and it was much better.
data.author: Peter Lehman

data.text: Wow why you need so much?
data.author: Adrian Tannous

data.text: I think if you took the kitchen sink and your pizza oven and golf clubs out of the paniers you’re good

data.text: If mechanical components are intact, your bags seem to add a lot if distortion to aerodynamics.

data.text: It sounds like you have to much stuff on your bike. Had that too 😊

data.text: My old Nishiki with an "extra wheel" made in Poland.

data.text: are your weels in one line?
data.author: Peter van Huffel

data.text: I always travel with my BOB trailer. Pulls great and holds everything I’ll ever need!! Keep pedaling ✌️

data.text: Looks overloaded. Reexamine your priorities and cut the weight by 40%. That handlebar bag looks huge and it's very high. This also brings up your centre of gravity in the front. I'd go with a much smaller one that only has the bare essentials you need to keep handy at all times.

data.text: Bringing a little less stuff... problem solved
data.author: Gertjan Hommema

data.text: Maybe front pannier is wobbling? Is it flexible? It happened on my bike.
data.author: Marek Dudziński

data.text: My experience with front wheel wobble was unequal weight in one front pannier. When I moved gear from the heavy bag to the ligh bag wheel wobble went away. For long distance self supported tours I use a Burley trailer on roads and a Bob trailer on trails. For short tours I only use as few panniers as possible based on availability of what I may need along my route. Be safe and never hurry.

data.text: I have the same problem with mine when carrying heavy loads. I redistribute to the back.

data.text: I'm just curious, but what is that under your Arkel handlebar bag? Is it there to transfer some of the weight from the bag's mounting brackets and, subsequently, preventing the bag from drooping downward?

data.text: It is a burlap camouflage. Not heavy and fits there well. Also makes for a better sleep. Pretty sure it saved my posterior at least once.

Watersources underway? Local food as an aspect that belongs to a journey?! Sleeping in a biviback or hammock instead of a tent? Thats outdoor- and life-art! Habe you got an emergency-, a bike-repair- and a first-aid-Kit in your bags? See ya

data.text: I had some bad frame wobble but found I had lost a bolt.. , a simple but easy thing to miss.

data.text: In my experience when the bike starts to wobble, if I didn't do it before, it's because a problem with the steering has arisen: I recommend disassemble the steering, clean it, change bearings, grease and TUNE IT.
data.author: Toñín Indignado

data.text: Get heavy gear as low as possible front and rear. Unless its super light you have too much on top of the front wheel. Reduce your load and bulk as much as possible.
data.author: Raym Richards

data.text: Several ideas to try: lower your total weight by using lightweight gear. Put the heaviest items at the bottom of the bags. Take only essentials, and those with multiple uses, like a bandana has many uses. I bought a digital fish scale and filed the sharp hook down. I weigh each pannier/bag. Both rear bags should weigh the same amount. Both front bags should weigh the same. Balance is the key to eliminating wobble. I had about 12-13 lbs in each rear bag, 6-7 in front bags, 5 in handlebar bag. Tent, etc on rear rack was 5 lbs. 50 lbs total and I was self-contained and ready for anything. Camping, motels, hostels and warm showers. KS to Connecticut last summer. 😋❤️🚴‍♀️
data.author: Joyce Riecker

data.text: It does look a little overladen.

data.author: Hayrettin Şensözlū

data.text: The handlebar bag may be the cause of your troubles. In my experience, weight on the front wheel that is /far/ from the steering axis causes speed wobbles. So the front panniers, close to the fork axis, should be fine. Try a test ride without the handlebar bag (or unload it substantially).
data.author: Mark Janeba

data.text: I have friends that still load their bikes up like that for cycle touring but once you gain experience most travellers realise that less is more. Your bike is trying to tell you something.
data.author: Neil Brown

data.text: Too much weight. I toured on a TDF 531 racebike and my packs and camping gear only weighed 23 lbs. My racebike w/o water bottle was 20.5 lbs

data.author: Wayne Croning

data.text: I think if you try and put the heavy stuff lower down, that might help, if it's even possible.
data.author: Simon Lambourn

data.text: You will need a much stiffer frame to stabilise that load. The Kona Sutra is a fantastic bike but like most steel touring bikes has a fair bit of flex built in for comfort. It may be an improvement on your current bike but I suspect you will spend thousands and still have the same problem. I have been cycle touring for over 40 years and cannot imagine how I could possibly handle a bike loaded up like yours. There are endless reasons why your best option is to carry less, and spend your money on the best lightweight compact equipment.
data.author: David Backhouse

data.text: Yes too much weight on top of front carrier and low tire pressure , secure the bags well. Get it of heavy clothing ( jeans,) and wash more?

data.text: Too much weight on top of front wheel, and off the back of bike. Load should be 65% rear/35%front. Move your tent to front top of rear rack, mounted across, bed roll behind. You probably need loose the blue bag under the HB bag. And the i would start trimming items.

data.author: Phill Collins

data.text: Check out Rodrigues cycles in Portland. R+e. They have your solution.
data.author: Marcus Murray

data.text: Curious why everyone thinks I have so much stuff. Front panniers were half empty, right rear had clothes, left rear aluminum pots, a stove, fuel and the tent. I have very little more than I did when I only used rear panniers, but now it is in four bags instead of 2. Lots of people travel with four panniers. Biggest weight was water, 2 of 2L in the Blackburn Cargo Cages plus a 650ml bottle on the stem. No wobble when full and without the bags. I did repack the food to the rear and the clothes to the front and that helped a lot. Best advice seems to be to redistribute the weight so that it is "between" the axles. This makes sense from a physics model. I am getting a "standing wave" and putting those vibrational forces outside the nodes seems to be the cause. Closing comments. Thanks all! Stay safe! Peace!
data.author: Peter Lehman
